required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Determining the Potential Benefit of Powered Prostheses
clinical_study.official_title: Determining the Potential Benefit of Powered Prostheses

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this research is to determine the effectiveness of a powered prosthesis compared to an unpowered prosthesis during short bouts of walking, extended periods of walking (to fatigue), and performance in the community.

detailed_description.textblock: Many individuals are living in the United States with limb loss. With the use of a prosthetic device many individuals can stay active, but most do not achieve a medically desired physical activity level. This creates a risk for cardiovascular disease. It is thought that individuals with amputation walk less because it is more difficult to get around, and recent advances in robotic prosthetic technology may make such activities easier. However, these prostheses have not yet been evaluated to determine their effectiveness during extended periods of walking. Despite the goals in design of new devices it is unclear whether individuals using them are able to incorporate them into making daily activities easier. Therefore, the goal of this research is to determine the effectiveness of a powered prosthesis compared to an unpowered prosthesis during long periods of walking.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Testing took place after wearing the prostheses for two weeks
primary_outcome.description: Metabolic costs will be measured using a portable metabolic system when participants walk on a treadmill at a fixed speed.

primary_outcome.measure: Total Steps Outside the Home Over a Two Week Period
primary_outcome.description: Activity data we be collected using activity monitors and GPS with both the regular prosthesis and the powered ankle prosthesis. Each activity monitoring period will last 2 weeks and will be done within in a 2 month period. Daily step count taken outside of the home, determined using an activity monitor and GPS device

primary_outcome.measure: Quality of Life (QoL) on a Short-Form 36
primary_outcome.time_frame: Questionnaire completed 2 weeks after wearing each prosthesis
primary_outcome.description: Participants completed the Medical Outcomes Study 36 Items Short-Form Health Survey (SF-36) after each condition. Each scale is directly transformed into a 0-100 scale on the assumption that each question carries equal weight. The lower the score the more disability.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Questionnaire completed 2 weeks after wearing each prosthesis
secondary_outcome.description: Participants completed a survey to evaluate their prosthetic satisfaction (Prosthetic Evaluation Questionnaire) after each condition. Most questions in the PEQ use a visual analog scale format. Each visual analog scale is scored as a continuous numerical variable measured as the distance in millimeters from the left endpoint of the line (0 mm) to the point at which the respondent's mark crosses the line (up to 100 mm). The questions are all worded so that a higher number (toward the right) will correspond with a more positive response. Ambulation - Greater number = increased perceived ambulation Appearance - Greater number = better appearance Frustration - Greater number = less frustration Perceived Response - Greater number = increased perceived response Residual Limb Health - Greater number = better residual limb health Social burden - Greater number = less social burden Sounds - Greater number = less sound Utility - Greater

secondary_outcome.measure: Muscle Activity in the Lower Limb
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Testing took place after the participant wore the prosthesis for 2 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Participants walk on a treadmill while muscle activity from various lower limb muscles are monitored using electromyography. We calculated the integrated EMG (iEMG) for each muscle collected as the total activity in that muscle as a percentage of the maximum signal.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Testing took place after wearing the prostheses for two weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Participants walk on a treadmill at a fast speed until they felt they can no longer continue. The time to fatigue was recorded.

arm_group.description: In this condition, the participant is fitted with a powered prosthetic ankle by a certified prosthetist. The ankle is the BiOM which is manufactured by Bionx (which used to be named iWalk). This device was given 510(K) Exempt status by the FDA under (regulation number: 890.3500). Participants will wear the device for 2 weeks.
In this arm, participants will wear their clinically prescribed dynamic response foot. This period is 2 weeks long.

intervention.description: This device is a commercially available powered ankle prosthesis, (BioM, Bionx, Bedford, MA) which was given FDA device exempt status.
This condition is a sham condition as the participant will wear the prosthesis they were clinically prescribed and usually wear.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult (over 21 years old), Has unilateral transtibial amputation, has used prosthesis for at least 6 months, is currently using an unpowered prosthesis, can walk unassisted for at least 10 minutes
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of orthopedic or neurologic disorders to their intact limb, history of cardiovascular disease that prevents them from safely completing requested activities, unable to walk for 30 minutes at a time

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment began after initial approval from the University of Michigan IRB (July 2016). Participants were recruited through the University of Michigan Orthotics and Prosthetics Clinic by a study physician and study prosthetist in-person, through phone or email, or with flyers.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Participants were asked to complete both arms of the study. Before starting, participants were randomly enrolled in the dynamic response foot (unpowered prosthesis) or powered condition to start with. Some participants completed both arms while others only finished one of the arms.

group.title: Powered Ankle Prosthesis, Then Unpowered Prosthesis
group.description: In this condition, the participant was fitted with a powered prosthetic ankle by a certified prosthetist to start the study. The ankle is the BiOM which is manufactured by Bionx (which used to be named iWalk). This device was given 510(K) Exempt status by the FDA under (regulation number: 890.3500). Participants had at least one week to acclimate to the prosthesis. They then will wore the device for 2 weeks at home, while their activity was monitored. They then came to the lab for testing. The powered prosthesis was removed and their prescribed prosthetic foot was reattached to their existing socket. They then wore their prescribed prosthesis for 2 weeks, while their activity was monitored, before returning to the lab for testing.

group.title: Unpowered Prosthesis, Then Powered Ankle Prosthesis
group.description: In this arm, participants will start in their clinically prescribed dynamic response foot. They first wore their prescribed prosthesis for 2 weeks, while their activity was monitored. They then came to the laboratory for testing. Participants were then fitted with a powered prosthetic ankle by a certified prosthetist. The ankle is the BiOM which is manufactured by Bionx (which used to be named iWalk). This device was given 510(K) Exempt status by the FDA under (regulation number: 890.3500). Participants had at least one week to acclimate to the prosthesis. They then will wore the device for 2 weeks at home, while their activity was monitored. They then came to the lab for testing. The powered prosthesis was removed and their prescribed prosthetic foot was reattached to their existing socket.

group.title: All Study Participants
group.description: This group represents all participants enrolled in the study.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Metabolic Cost of Walking
outcome.description: Metabolic costs will be measured using a portable metabolic system when participants walk on a treadmill at a fixed speed.
outcome.time_frame: Testing took place after wearing the prostheses for two weeks
outcome.population: Each participant wore both study prostheses. One participant was excluded from analysis as he was not able to reach steady-state energetics on a treadmill

group.title: Unpowered Prosthesis
group.description: This condition is any unpowered prosthesis that was clinically prescribed to the patient

group.title: BiOM Powered Prosthesis
group.description: This device is a prosthetic ankle which is battery powered and supplies active ankle power.

measure.title: Metabolic Cost of Walking
measure.description: Metabolic costs will be measured using a portable metabolic system when participants walk on a treadmill at a fixed speed.
measure.population: Each participant wore both study prostheses. One participant was excluded from analysis as he was not able to reach steady-state energetics on a treadmill

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was that there would be no difference in metabolic costs between the two groups
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical significance was set a-priori at p<0.05

outcome.title: Total Steps Outside the Home Over a Two Week Period
outcome.description: Activity data we be collected using activity monitors and GPS with both the regular prosthesis and the powered ankle prosthesis. Each activity monitoring period will last 2 weeks and will be done within in a 2 month period. Daily step count taken outside of the home, determined using an activity monitor and GPS device
outcome.population: Each participant in the study wore both prostheses

measure.population: Each participant in the study wore both prostheses

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was that there were no differences in the number of steps taken outside of the home for the two prostheses.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical significance was set a-priori at p<0.05

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: paired t-test of Physical component scores between the two conditions
analysis.p_value_desc: a prior threshold for significance was 0.05
Statistical significance was set a-priori at p<0.05

outcome.title: Prosthetic Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ)
outcome.description: Participants completed a survey to evaluate their prosthetic satisfaction (Prosthetic Evaluation Questionnaire) after each condition. Most questions in the PEQ use a visual analog scale format. Each visual analog scale is scored as a continuous numerical variable measured as the distance in millimeters from the left endpoint of the line (0 mm) to the point at which the respondent's mark crosses the line (up to 100 mm). The questions are all worded so that a higher number (toward the right) will correspond with a more positive response. Ambulation - Greater number = increased perceived ambulation Appearance - Greater number = better appearance Frustration - Greater number = less frustration Perceived Response - Greater number = increased perceived response Residual Limb Health - Greater number = better residual limb health Social burden - Greater number = less social burden Sounds - Greater number = less sound Utility - Greater
outcome.time_frame: Questionnaire completed 2 weeks after wearing each prosthesis
outcome.population: Each participant wore both study prostheses.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events were monitored through study completion for each participant, which was approximately 3 months time.
reported_events.desc: If an adverse event were to occur, it would be reported to the University of Michigan IRB and study sponsor for review.

group.title: Powered Ankle Prosthesis
group.description: In this condition, the participant is fitted with a powered prosthetic ankle by a certified prosthetist. The ankle is the BiOM which is manufactured by Bionx (which used to be named iWalk). This device was given 510(K) Exempt status by the FDA under (regulation number: 890.3500). After accommodation, participants wore the device for 2 weeks. Powered ankle prosthesis: This device is a commercially available powered ankle prosthesis, (BioM, Bionx, Bedford, MA) which was given FDA device exempt status. We monitored for adverse events the entire time the participant had the device at home for accommodation and monitoring (~ 3 weeks)

group.title: Unpowered Prosthesis
group.description: In this arm, participants will wear their clinically prescribed dynamic response foot (unpowered prosthesis). This period is 2 weeks long. Dynamic Response Foot: This condition is a sham condition as the participant will wear the prosthesis they were clinically prescribed and usually wear. We monitored for adverse events the entire time the person wore their device at home and were monitored (2 weeks).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
